abstract.Definition: The abstract keyword marks a class or member as incomplete and meant to be inherited. Abstract members must be implemented by derived classes.

add.Definition: The add keyword defines how a handler is attached to an event. It runs when code subscribes to the event.

alias.Definition: The alias keyword creates an alternate name for a namespace or type. It helps simplify long or conflicting names.

and.Definition: The and keyword is used in pattern matching to require multiple conditions to be true. All parts of the pattern must match.

as.Definition: The as keyword attempts to convert a value to a specified type. If the conversion fails, it returns null instead of throwing an error.

ascending.Definition: The ascending keyword sorts query results from lowest to highest. It is commonly used in LINQ order-by expressions.

async.Definition: The async keyword marks a method as asynchronous. It allows the method to run without blocking while waiting for work to finish.

await.Definition: The await keyword pauses execution until an asynchronous operation completes. It allows the program to continue doing other work while waiting.

base.Definition: The base keyword refers to a base class from which the current class inherits. It is used to access base class members.

bool.Definition: The bool keyword defines a Boolean value. It can hold either true or false.

by.Definition: The by keyword specifies how data should be grouped or ordered in a query. It works with keywords like group and order.

byte.Definition: The byte keyword defines a small numeric type that stores whole numbers from 0 to 255. It is often used for raw data and memory-efficient storage.

break.Definition: The break keyword immediately exits a loop or switch statement. Execution continues with the next statement after the block.

case.Definition: The case keyword defines a branch in a switch statement. It specifies what code runs when a value matches.

catch.Definition: The catch keyword handles errors that occur in a try block. It allows a program to respond to exceptions safely.

char.Definition: The char keyword defines a single character value. It is written using single quotes, such as 'A'.

checked.Definition: The checked keyword enables overflow checking for numeric operations. It causes an error if a calculation exceeds the allowed range.

class.Definition: The class keyword defines a class, which is a blueprint for creating objects. Classes group related data and behavior together.

const.Definition: The const keyword defines a value that cannot be changed after it is set. Constant values are known at compile time.

continue.Definition: The continue keyword skips the rest of the current loop iteration. Execution continues with the next iteration of the loop.

decimal.Definition: The decimal keyword defines a high-precision numeric type. It is commonly used for financial and monetary calculations.

default.Definition: The default keyword provides a fallback value or action when no other option matches. It is commonly used in switch statements and default expressions.

delegate.Definition: The delegate keyword defines a type that represents a method reference. It allows methods to be passed and invoked indirectly.

descending.Definition: The descending keyword sorts query results from highest to lowest. It is used in LINQ order-by expressions.

do.Definition: The do keyword starts a loop that runs at least once. The loop continues while a condition remains true.

double.Definition: The double keyword defines a floating-point numeric type. It is used for numbers with decimal values.

dynamic.Definition: The dynamic keyword defers type checking until runtime. It allows flexible behavior but removes compile-time type safety.

else.Definition: The else keyword defines code that runs when an if condition is false. It provides an alternative execution path.

enum.Definition: The enum keyword defines a set of named constant values. It is used to represent a fixed list of options.

equals.Definition: The equals keyword specifies a value comparison in pattern matching. It checks whether two values are equal.

event.Definition: The event keyword defines a notification that other code can subscribe to. It allows objects to react when something happens.

explicit.Definition: The explicit keyword defines a conversion that must be written by the programmer. It prevents accidental or unsafe type conversions.

false.Definition: The false keyword represents a Boolean value that means something is not true. It is commonly used in conditions and logical expressions.

file.Definition: The file keyword applies certain declarations to a single source file. It helps limit visibility and avoid name conflicts.

finally.Definition: The finally keyword defines code that always runs after a try or catch block. It is commonly used for cleanup tasks.

fixed.Definition: The fixed keyword prevents data from being moved by the garbage collector. It is used when working with pointers in unsafe code.

float.Definition: The float keyword defines a floating-point numeric type. It is used for numbers with decimal values and less precision than double.

for.Definition: The for keyword starts a loop that runs a set number of times. It is commonly used when the number of iterations is known.

foreach.Definition: The foreach keyword loops through each item in a collection. It simplifies working with lists and arrays.

from.Definition: The from keyword specifies the data source in a LINQ query. It defines where the query begins.

get.Definition: The get keyword defines how a property’s value is retrieved. It runs when the property is read.

global.Definition: The global keyword refers to the global namespace or scope. It helps avoid naming conflicts.

group.Definition: The group keyword groups query results based on a key. It is used in LINQ queries to organize data.

goto.Definition: The goto keyword jumps execution to a labeled statement. It is rarely used because it can make code harder to follow.

if.Definition: The if keyword runs code only when a condition is true. It allows programs to make decisions.

implicit.Definition: The implicit keyword defines a conversion that happens automatically. It allows safe type conversions without extra syntax.

in.Definition: The in keyword is used to iterate over collections or specify input-only parameters. It indicates that values are read but not modified.

init.Definition: The init keyword allows a property to be set only during object creation. It helps create immutable objects.

int.Definition: The int keyword defines a whole number type. It is commonly used for counting and indexing.

interface.Definition: The interface keyword defines a contract that classes must follow. It specifies what members a class must implement.

internal.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}internal{/c} members are accessible from any code within the same assembly but not from other assemblies.

into.Definition: The into keyword continues a query after a group or join operation. It allows further processing of query results.

is.Definition: The is keyword checks whether a value matches a given type or pattern. It is commonly used in conditions.

join.Definition: The join keyword combines data from two sources based on a related value. It is used in LINQ queries to match items.

let.Definition: The let keyword stores the result of an expression in a temporary variable. It helps simplify complex queries.

lock.Definition: The lock keyword prevents multiple threads from accessing the same code at the same time. It helps avoid data corruption.

long.Definition: The long keyword defines a whole number type that can store very large values. It is larger than int.

managed.Definition: The managed keyword specifies that code is managed by the runtime. It is used in advanced interoperability scenarios.

nameof.Definition: The nameof keyword returns the name of a variable, type, or member as a string. It helps avoid hard-coded names.

namespace.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}namespace{/c} keyword groups related types into a named scope, helping organize code and prevent naming conflicts across large projects.

new.Definition: The new keyword creates a new instance of a type. It allocates memory and initializes the object.

nint.Definition: The nint keyword defines an integer whose size depends on the platform. It is commonly used in low-level or interop code.

not.Definition: The not keyword negates a pattern or condition. It matches when the pattern does not apply.

notnull.Definition: The notnull keyword constrains a generic type to non-null values. It ensures null is not allowed.

nuint.Definition: The nuint keyword defines an unsigned integer whose size depends on the platform. It is used for low-level or interop scenarios.

null.Definition: The null keyword represents the absence of a value or object reference. It means nothing is assigned.

object.Definition: The object keyword represents the base type of all types in C#. Every type ultimately derives from object.

on.Definition: The on keyword specifies the condition used to match items in a join query. It defines how data sources are related.

operator.Definition: The operator keyword defines a custom operator for a type. It controls how operators like + or == behave.

or.Definition: The or keyword is used in pattern matching to allow alternative matches. At least one condition must be true.

orderby.Definition: The orderby keyword sorts query results. It is commonly used in LINQ expressions.

out.Definition: The out keyword passes a variable by reference to a method. The method assigns the value before returning.

override.Definition: The override keyword replaces a base class method with a new implementation. It allows derived classes to change behavior.

params.Definition: The params keyword allows a method to accept a variable number of arguments. It simplifies passing multiple values.

partial.Definition: The partial keyword splits a class, struct, or method across multiple files. It helps organize large codebases.

private.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}private{/c} members are only accessible within the class or struct in which they are declared.

protected.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}protected{/c} members are accessible within the containing class and by derived (child) classes.

public.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}public{/c} members are accessible from any other code in the same assembly or another assembly that references it.

readonly.Definition: The readonly keyword allows a field to be assigned only during initialization. It prevents modification after construction.

record.Definition: The record keyword defines a data-focused type with value-based equality. It is commonly used for immutable data.

ref.Definition: The ref keyword passes a variable by reference. Changes made inside the method affect the original value.

remove.Definition: The remove keyword defines how a handler is detached from an event. It runs when code unsubscribes from the event.

required.Definition: The required keyword enforces that a property must be set during object creation. It helps ensure objects are properly initialized.

return.Definition: The return keyword sends a value back from a method and ends its execution. It defines the result of the method.

sbyte.Definition: The sbyte keyword defines a small signed numeric type. It stores whole numbers from -128 to 127.

sealed.Definition: The sealed keyword prevents a class from being inherited. It locks the class so it cannot be extended.

select.Definition: The select keyword chooses which values are returned from a query. It defines the shape of the query result.

set.Definition: The set keyword defines how a property’s value is assigned. It runs when a property is written to.

short.Definition: The short keyword defines a small whole number type. It stores values from -32,768 to 32,767.

sizeof.Definition: The sizeof keyword returns the size of a type in bytes. It is mainly used in low-level or unsafe code.

stackalloc.Definition: The stackalloc keyword allocates memory on the stack instead of the heap. It is used for high-performance or low-level scenarios.

static.Definition: The static keyword defines members that belong to a type rather than an instance. Static members are shared across all objects.

string.Definition: The string keyword defines a sequence of characters. It is commonly used to represent text.

struct.Definition: The struct keyword defines a value type that groups related data together. Structs are often used for small, lightweight objects.

switch.Definition: The switch keyword selects which code to run based on a value or pattern. It provides a clear alternative to multiple if statements.

this.Definition: The this keyword refers to the current instance of a class or struct. It is used to access instance members.

throw.Definition: The throw keyword raises an exception. It signals that an error has occurred.

true.Definition: The true keyword represents a Boolean value that means something is correct or enabled. It is used in logical expressions.

try.Definition: The try keyword wraps code that might cause an error. It works with catch and finally to handle exceptions.

typeof.Definition: The typeof keyword gets information about a type at runtime. It returns a Type object.

uint.Definition: The uint keyword defines an unsigned whole number type. It stores values from 0 to 4,294,967,295.

ulong.Definition: The ulong keyword defines a very large unsigned whole number type. It is used when extremely large values are needed.

unmanaged.Definition: The unmanaged keyword restricts a generic type to unmanaged types. It ensures the type does not contain managed references.

ushort.Definition: The ushort keyword defines a small unsigned whole number type. It stores values from 0 to 65,535.

unchecked.Definition: The unchecked keyword disables overflow checking for numeric operations. It allows calculations to wrap without errors.

unsafe.Definition: The unsafe keyword allows code to use pointers and direct memory access. It bypasses some safety checks.

using.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}using{/c} keyword imports namespaces into the file so you can reference their types without fully qualifying their names.

value.Definition: The value keyword represents the value being assigned to a property or indexer. It is used inside a set or init accessor.

var.Definition: The var keyword lets the compiler infer the type of a variable from its assigned value. The variable still has a strong, fixed type.

virtual.Definition: The virtual keyword allows a method or property to be overridden in a derived class. It supports customizable behavior through inheritance.

void.Definition: The return type {c:color-blue keyword}void{/c} means the method does not return anything. The point of execution will return to where the method was called from but no data will be returned with it.

volatile.Definition: The volatile keyword ensures a field is always read from and written to main memory. It helps prevent issues in multi-threaded code.

when.Definition: The when keyword adds a condition to a catch block or pattern match. It controls when the code should run.

where.Definition: The where keyword filters data in a query or applies constraints to generic types. It limits which values or types are allowed.

while.Definition: The while keyword starts a loop that runs as long as a condition is true. The condition is checked before each iteration.

with.Definition: The with keyword creates a copy of an object with selected values changed. It is commonly used with records.

yield.Definition: The yield keyword returns values one at a time from a method. It allows lazy iteration over a sequence.
